STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 22, 2019
Laura Nye
Branch County DHHS
388 Keith Wilhelm Dr
Coldwater, MI 49036
RE: License #: CP120200999
Branch County DHHS
388 Keith Wilhelm Dr
Coldwater, MI 49036
Dear Ms. Nye:
Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on (date). Due to
the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP and your contract. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For any repeat
violations, please address what steps were taken in the previous CAP,
what was successful and what will be changed for the new CAP.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP120200999
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Laura Nye, Administrator
Jooyeun Chang, Designee
Name of Facility: Branch County DHHS
Facility Address: 388 Keith Wilhelm Dr
Coldwater, MI 49036
Facility Telephone #: (517) 279-4200
Original Issuance Date: 10/01/1993
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
1

Date of On-site Inspection(s): 9/25/19-10/10/19

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
One of three foster home files held a renewal evaluation that was not completed in
the time frame specified by this rule. The report was approved on 10/2/18, but the
license expired on 10/11/18.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a)Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Two of eight foster care case files held late service plans. One ISP was completed
31 days after the youth entered care. One USP was completed 92 days after the
previous report.
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(b),
shall include all of the following information:
(c) A summary of information pertinent to the updated
services plan received since the last service plan from the child,
the child's parents or legal guardian, foster parents, referring
agency, and others, unless the agency documents why any of
these entities cannot be involved.
Two of eight service plans did not provide updated information as required.
Information in the service plans was lacking and/or clearly copy/pasted from the
previous report and not updated.
R 400.12403 Policy and procedures
(1)An agency shall have and follow written policies and procedures
for the foster care services provided. (2) The policies and
4

procedure shall cover at least all of the following areas: (j)
Visitation.
The facility is found to be in violation due to four areas in which visitation policy
(FOM 722-06H & 06I- Maintaining Connections Through Visitation and Contact) was
not followed.
Parental contact
 One file was missing a parental home visit for September 2019
 One file was missing face to face contact with the parents from February to
June 2019.
 One file was missing all quarterly face to face home visits with the parent,
with the exception of 5/23/19.
Parenting time
 One file did not have parenting time documented from February-August 2019,
without a documented exception for May-August 2019.
 One file did not have any parenting time documented. No exception was
documented.
Sibling visits
 One file did not have sibling visits documented for January and August 2019.
 One file did not have sibling visits documented from February to May 2019.
Unannounced visits
 One file did not have unannounced visits completed from October 2018- July
2019. The supervisor reported that the visits were all unannounced, but
documented incorrectly.
This is a repeat violation from the 1/7/19 interim review (CAP approved
1/29/19), 10/4/17 renewal (CAP approved 11/7/17), and 10/4/16 interim (CAP
approved 11/30/16).
R 400.12405 Change of placement
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child’s
record before a change of placement…
Two of eight foster care case files did not have the proper documentation for a
change of placement (DHHS 69).
This is a repeat violation from the 1/7/19 interim inspection (CAP approved
1/29/19), and the 10/4/17 renewal (CAP approved 11/7/17)
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional ISEP requirements, except for the following:
5

ISEP 6.24 Caseload, Foster Care Workers
Page 26
(a) 95% of foster care caseworkers shall have a caseload of no
more than 15 children.
Per the caseload count on 12/28/18, only 86% of foster care staff had caseloads of
15 children or less. Per the caseload count on 10/9/19, only 75% of foster care staff
had caseloads of 15 children or less. During the on-site visit for this review, it was
determined that caseloads were at 19, 18, 17, and 15.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-08C Parent Agency Treatment Plan- required participation in
Page 2 development
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS office
designee.
Six of eight foster care USP/PATP were missing required signatures.
This is a repeat violation from the 1/7/19 interim review (CAP approved
1/29/19), 10/4/17 renewal (CAP approved 11/7/17), and the 10/4/16 interim (CAP
approved 11/30/16)
FOM 722-06H Timely Entry of Caseworker Contacts
All caseworker contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS; this
includes attempted contacts and missed appointments, and all
pertinent information obtained must be summarized and included
in the appropriate section of the case service plan.
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, within five
business days of the contact.
Three of eight case files had contacts that were not entered within the required
timeframe.
File one: Almost all June, July and August contacts were entered on 8/27/19.
File two & three: All contacts were entered. However, they were entered outside of
the 5 day requirement.
6

This is a repeat violation from the 1/7/19 interim review (CAP approved 1/29/19)
and 10/4/16 interim review (CAP approved 10/30/16).
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
Page 1-7
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined…
Four FTMs were missing the completed 1105 report.
One FTM did not occurred prior to a USP in August 2019.
This is a repeat violation from the 1/7/19 interim review (CAP approved 1/29/19)
and the 10/4/17 renewal (CAP approved 11/7/17)
FOM 722-03B Relative Engagement and Placement
Pages 14-19
(Page 14) The DHS-588, Initial Relative Safety Screen, is used to
examine basic qualifications of a prospective caregiver and to
identify immediate safety concerns in the caregiver's home. The
Relative Safety Screen must be completed and approved prior to,
but no more than 30 calendar days before a child's placement. 4
(Page 19) The Relative Placement Home Study (3130A) including
all clearances must be completed and approved annually (within
365 days of the previous Relative Placement Home Study
completion date) for unlicensed caregivers. An approved Relative
Placement Home Study is valid for one year.
Two relative placement were found to be in violation of this policy.
One relative accepted placement on 10/18/18. A 588 safety screen was not
completed until 11/1/18. It was noted that this was a court ordered placement,
however a safety screen is still required at the time of placement.
One relative had a 3130A which was last updated on 9/12/18. The agency is in
violation as an update is due annually and one was not completed as of October
2019.
FOM 801 Medical Passport
Page 11-13
All medical information within the medical passport must be current
and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's current and
complete health information…
Four of eight case files did not have medical passports as required.
File One: The file only had one medical passport during the past year.
7

File Two: The file was missing three quarterly updated passports for the past year.
File Three: The file was missing a quarterly report for January 2019.
File four: A quarterly updated medical passport was not completed from February to
July 2019.
This is a repeat violation from the 1/7/19 interim inspection (CAP approved
1/29/19) and 10/4/17 renewal (CAP approved 11/7/17) .
FOM 722-03 Placement Exception Request
Page 14-16
Caseworkers must complete a placement exception request (PER)
when there is a need to waive placement standards to maintain
sibling and caregiver bonds or to meet the medical, emotional, and
psychological needs of children in care. PERs must be completed,
reviewed, and approved in MiSACWIS.
One of eight foster care files was missing a PER for a sibling split during July-
August 2019.
ANALYST SAFETY CONCERNS
Safety Alert 1: The infant is currently sleeping in a drop side crib. The foster
placement indicated that they were unaware this was a safe sleep issue. The foster
home stated that previous to the crib that the child was sleeping in a pack and play
since she was placed with them. There is not a variance request in MiSACWIS for
the child to sleep in a pack and play instead of a crib.
Upon receipt of this alert, the foster parent was contacted by the agency. An
appropriate crib was placed in the home as observed by the foster care worker on
7/9/19. The infant has slept in the crib every night since that time.
Safety Alert 2: The relative placement indicated that they do not have a carbon
monoxide detector.
Upon receiving this notification, the agency contacted the relative caregiver and a
carbon monoxide detector was installed.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
MiSACWIS documents: The agency asked about utilizing the “documents” section in
MiSACWIS case records, for all case documents. The agency was reminded that
that MiSACWIS flow chart must be utilized when uploading documents.
8

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Information was relayed to the administrator and supervisors, regarding the
interviews conducted with foster care staff. Staff reported having difficulty
communicating with co-workers in children’s services at the initiation of cases. They
expressed that they are two very different units and this divide sets the tone for new
cases. Workers also reported not getting vital documents in a timely manner at the
early stages of the case. The Supervisors expressed that they recently had a
meeting with the children’s services supervisor, and put a plan together to address
these concerns. Several strategies were identified, which will be utilized to bring the
two units together.
It was also shared with supervisors that caseworkers are overwhelmed by the case
load sizes. Supervisors expressed that two staff are currently on medical leave and
one staff left the agency recently. The supervisors are confident that once they are
back to a full staff, case numbers will return to normal. Until then, Supervisors are
doing what they can to support and assist their staff.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The CAP, approved 1/29/19, was required after the 1/7/19 interim evaluation. While
there were some repeat violations during this review period, the agency has shown
improvement in many other areas. No significant safety issues have been identified
and all violations appear to be correctable with a Corrective Action Plan, and lower
caseloads.
9

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, ISEP requirements, or MDHHS contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
October 17, 2019
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 22, 2019
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
10
